docs.lead_paragraph: AMONG a planeload of passengers there is almost always a doctor, nurse or medical technician, but when an airliner is at cruise altitude, the nearest equipment to diagnose or treat a heart attack is usually seven miles below. Now, however, American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and Alaska Airlines are equipping their planes with a machine that is a combination heart monitor and defibrillator -- that is, a device that produces an EKG, and one that shocks the heart back into normal rhythm if necessary. The device is already credited with saving one passenger's life, on a flight from Dallas to Mexico City on Feb. 18, and has helped many other times to determine whether a stricken passenger was, in fact, having a heart attack.

headline.main: Airlines Prepare to Fight Heart Attacks Aloft

docs.snippet: AMONG a planeload of passengers there is almost always a doctor, nurse or medical technician, but when an airliner is at cruise altitude, the nearest equipment to diagnose or treat a heart attack is usually seven miles below.     Now, however,...

docs.lead_paragraph: IT has become an article of faith among those who oppose abortion in the United States that promoting abortion anywhere else, particularly in the world's poorest countries, is tantamount to an attack on the cultures of those countries. It is a new argument from the conservative right, but it echoes charges that the radical left used to make, to the effect that family planning programs targeted at the third world were a kind of neo-imperialistic genocide. A statistical look around the world shows that if cultural sensitivities are reflected in laws about abortion, there is a remarkable divide between richer countries and poorer ones where abortion and its effects are concerned. But other statistics demonstrate that the pattern of legality does not reflect how women in those societies choose to act. Unequal Death Rates In the global south, where abortion laws are the most restrictive, abortion rates are still quite high; deaths from abortion are much higher there than elsewhere, because the abortions tend to be unsafe. The industrial countries of the global north are almost universally less restrictive in their abortion laws. They also have the lowest rates of abortion-related deaths.

headline.main: The World; A Global Divide on Abortion Splits Poor From Rich

docs.lead_paragraph: THE kids were in school. His wife was at work. So 44-year-old Howard Pallay, a chiropractor and nutritionist from Manhasset whose office hours didn't start until the afternoon, played a round of golf. ''It's an obsession,'' said Dr. Pallay, coming off the nine-hole course at Christopher Morley Park in Roslyn at 10 A.M. the other day. He plays at Bethpage State Park every Wednesday, the Nassau County-operated Morley Park on Fridays.

headline.main: An Island Gone Ga-Ga For a Little White Ball

docs.lead_paragraph: The night of fights at Madison Square Garden, once one of boxing's glamorous stages, had been advertised as D-Day, a mix of bouts that included Evander Holyfield, a heavyweight champion; Roberto Duran, an aging legend, and Christy Martin, the boxing world's top-ranked woman. Despite weeks of promotion, the fights had failed to generate much excitement, and yesterday the event unraveled completely after a series of strange developments: two fighters tested positive for hepatitis, Martin's opponent turned out to be pregnant and promoters were ordered by a Florida court to withhold any payment to Duran because he owed thousands of dollars in unpaid child support.

headline.main: A Big Night of Fights Suffers a Knockout

docs.abstract: Series of strange mishaps forces cancellation of a highly promoted evening of boxing at Madison Square Garden barely 24 hours before it was to start; Henry Akinwande, who was to face Evander Holyfield in a heavyweight title bout, tests positive to hepatitis B; so does Ray Mercer, who is on the undercard; Maria Nieves-Garcia is found to be pregnant and cannot fight Christy Martin, the top-ranked woman boxer; Florida court orders promoters, Don King Productions, to withhold any payment to Roberto Duran, the aging legend who was also scheduled to fight, because he owes thousands of dollars in child support; fights failed to generate much excitement despite the heavy promotion; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Maria Nieves-Garcia got a surprise during her prefight medical examination for her bout at Madison Square Garden tomorrow: She found out she was pregnant. Yesterday, when a third test confirmed what Nieves-Garcia could not believe, she was scratched from the bout. A 21-year-old from Mexico City who has a son, Nieves-Garcia was scheduled to fight Christy Martin on the undercard of the Evander Holyfield-Henry Akinwande heavyweight championship bout.

headline.main: Fighter Scratched From Bout: She's 21 Weeks Pregnant

docs.abstract: Maria Nieves-Garcia, scheduled to fight Christy Martin on undercard of Evander Holyfield-Henry Akinwande heavyweight championship bout at Madison Square Garden, is scratched from bout after prefight medical exam reveals she is pregnant; at Holyfield-Akinwande weigh-in, Holyfield weighs in at 218 1/2 pounds and Akinwande weighs in at 240 1/4 pounds; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved a powerful combination of two antiviral drugs to treat chronic hepatitis C, a liver infection that can lead to cirrhosis, liver cancer and liver failure. Four million Americans are estimated to have chronic hepatitis C, and 10,000 die from it each year. The disease, which is mainly spread by contaminated needles and other exposure to infected blood, is the leading reason for liver transplants.

headline.main: Drug Therapy Is Approved For Fighting Hepatitis C

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration approves powerful combination of two antiviral drugs to treat chronic hepatitis C, liver infection that can lead to cirrhosis, liver cancer and liver failure; four million Americans are estimated to have chronic hepatitis C, and 10,000 die from it each year; newly approved treatment, Rebetron, which is made by Schering-Plough Corp and consists of six-month course of interferon injections and ribavirin capsules (M)

byline.original: By GLENN COLLINS with James Barron

docs.lead_paragraph: In a panic when she found herself pregnant for the first time three years ago, Fernande Aka, a slender, soft-spoken high school senior, drank a concoction of nearly frozen Coca-Cola and wine mixed with a heavy dose of sugar that her schoolmates swore would make an unwanted pregnancy go away. When that didn't work, she felt she had no choice but to approach her mother, who took her to a public hospital and after hushed hallway negotiations with medical personnel there paid $60 for an abortion.

headline.main: On Africa's Back Streets, Abortions Take Heavy Toll

docs.abstract: Complications from illegal abortions are among leading causes of death of women of childbearing age in Africa; most African governments bar abortion and legal status of abortion gets little public attention; map; graph; photo (M)
